awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Experimental and theoretical study on the structure and catalytic activity of metal cluster/metal oxide interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
1033000
Batzill

The most successful metal/metal oxide catalysts currently available involve highly-dispersed, low-concentration metal atoms embedded in a metal oxide surface. Palladium metal supported on cerium oxide, is an important example of a highly active catalyst, with applications as an automotive three-way catalyst, in catalytic combustion, and as a solid oxide fuel cell anode material. The activity of these metal/metal oxide catalysts can be uniquely controlled by the support surface structure. Furthermore, these low-concentration metal catalysts have demonstrated significant resistance against sintering, a common multi-component catalyst degradation mechanism, thus indicating superior resistance to heating/cooling cycles and changes in redox enviroment. However, the structure of the active site is challenging to define at the atomistic scale. For the metal-ceria (M/CeO2) catalytic system, dynamic restructuring occurs under reaction conditions and both the ceria and metal structure alter reactivity. 

So how then to explain the catalytic and performance behaviors of Pd on ceria? Three Investigators, A.C. van Duin and M. J. Janik of Pennsylvania State University and M. M. Batzill of the University of South Florida, hypothesize that mixed surface oxides of Ce1-xPdxO2-d may provide unique active sites with high activity and stability under certain reaction conditions. To confirm this and in order to fully develop the potential of Pd/CeOx and similar metal/metal oxide catalysts, they believe a detailed, atomistic-scale knowledge of the catalytic conversion mechanisms and the surface dynamics related to substrate-surface interactions is required for the Pd/ceria system. In a collaborative study, the PIs propose to utilize atomistic simulation with Reactive Force-Field (ReaxFF) and Density Functional Theory (DFT) approaches together with experimental surface science studies to investigate the dynamic structure and reactivity of Pd/CeO2 systems. The combined surface science and ReaxFF/DFT approach will provide detailed determination of the structure, stability, and activity of Ce1-xPdxO2-?Ô?nmixed oxide surfaces. This will help answer questions about this catalyst system.

From the broader perspective, the combination of experimental and computational approaches applied to this complex catalytic system will advance the fundamental understanding of the effect of reducible oxide supports on catalyst stability and activity, as well as provide guidance towards the preparation of highly active M/CeO2 catalysts. Further, the development of an integrated, two-component simulation environment, which is validated against experiment is the outcome of this project. This collaboration between simulation and experiment will provide a roadmap for future catalytic research; the computational tools developed here are generally applicable, thus providing straightforward extension to other catalytic materials.

The research program also closely integrates education and outreach activities. Specifically, at PSU, courses for engineers on atomistic-scale simulation methods will be introduced, which will be complemented by lectures and tutorials on experimental techniques.

por.por_cntn:
Heterogeneous catalysts are one major driving force of our economy for the refinement of fuels and making of materials. Despite the central role catalysts play in our technology they are often poorly understood and thus improving catalysts is often an empirical process. Looking towards the future it is obvious that computational methods should play a more important role in screening materials for potentially useful catalytic properties. One challenge the development of better computational methods faces is their reliable testing against real materials systems. Because of the complex nature of most heterogeneous catalysts it is challenging to really understand how the computational methods predict the system and what needs to be done to improve the computational approach. Therefore this collaborative project between computational scientists and our experimental group aimed at describing simplified planar model systems. Experimentally, planar single crystalline materials can be characterized by a variety of methods with higher precision than the complex morphology of real catalysts. Thus one main goal on the experimental side was to develop methods for synthesizing well defined surfaces and investigate how surface modifications affect the structure and property. These results were then compared to theoretical predictions of how the system should behave. This comparison allowed judging and refinement of the computational methods.

This project had several specific thrusts. One was the improvement of the lab infrastructure that now enables the growth of single-crystalline oxide films by pulsed laser deposition. This improved facility will serve us for a long time into the future for making unique model catalysts and train graduate students in the science of oxide film growth. The other two thrusts were to prepare and characterize transition metal catalysts, in particular palladium, on planar substrates. In one thrust we investigated the role of adsorbed hydrogen on the agglomeration and sintering of Pd-atoms and clusters. This was characterized with atomic-precision using scanning tunneling microscopy and our experimental result were reproduced by computational methods. This showed the validity of some of the computational methods and in addition gave more physical details of the experimental results. In the third thrust we studied the oxidation behavior of Pd-clusters supported on ZnO single crystals. This study revealed the oxidation behavior of Pd, which is important for certain oxidation catalysis reactions. We showed that there exists a size regime for the Pd-clusters where they may oxidize much more readily than bulk Pd does. In these latter studies we also employed synchrotron facilities at Brookhaven National Lab.

Overall 3 graduate students and 3 post-docs were involved in some aspects of this research. Thus the funds spend also contributed largely to the training of the next generation of scientists and engineers.
